en: Interview with Michelle Childs, professor with the Retail, Hospitality, and Tourism Management department of UT. Childs discusses the effects of the wildfire on the businesses in Gatlinburg primarily over an extended time frame. She talks about the preparedness of businesses with contacting employees during the fire and in terms of insurance coverage. She also elaborates on the initial return of tourists to the area, and the steady recovery of the area. This is a representative quote from the interview: "What was really interesting because likely its such a small, tightknit community that those personal stories were really intertwined with the business stories."

How long have you lived in East Tennessee?
Tell us a little about your career path and your role at the university?
Can you tell us about your research in the area outside of the fire?
Can you tell us about the days leading up to the fire?
Can you talk about when you and your colleagues decided this would be a good research topic?
What was the scope of your research project and its methodologies?
Tell us about the types of businesses that you focused on.
What were the interviews you conducted like and how long after the fire were they?
So social media played a large roll?
What was the differences you saw between local businesses and franchis businesses?
Did some of the business owners question about whether to open again?
How were the businesses able to bring tourism back?
Did the business owner mention any other ways in which they were supported during recovery?
Did you find that people had begun making preparations in case something were to happen again?
Are there any other surprising aspects you would like to share?
What are some impacts of your research on the disclipine's understanding of disaster preparedness?
Can you tell us about how this study will help the understanding of disasers and climate change?
Any thing else you would like to add?

seo.title: Interview with Michelle Childs, 2019-11-09 - Rising From the Ashes Oral Histories
